vulnerability_findings.name: inefficient-state-variable-increment
vulnerability_findings.message: <x> += <y> costs more gas than <x> = <x> + <y> for state variables.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-nested-if
vulnerability_findings.message: Using nested is cheaper than using && multiple check combinations. There are more advantages, such as easier to read code and better coverage reports.

vulnerability_findings.name: arbitrary-send
vulnerability_findings.message:
GolemNetworkToken.finalize (Faucet.sol#173-196) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- ! golemFactory.send(this.balance) (Faucet.sol#195)

vulnerability_findings.name: unused-return
vulnerability_findings.message:
Faucet.create (Faucet.sol#234-238) does not use the value returned by external calls:
	-token.transfer(msg.sender,tokens) (Faucet.sol#237)

vulnerability_findings.name: external-function
vulnerability_findings.message: MigrationAgent.migrateFrom (Faucet.sol#7) should be declared external

vulnerability_findings.name: external-function
vulnerability_findings.message: GolemNetworkToken.transfer (Faucet.sol#76-89) should be declared external

vulnerability_findings.name: solc-version
vulnerability_findings.message:
Detected issues with version pragma in Faucet.sol:
	- pragma solidity^0.4.16 (Faucet.sol#4): it allows old versions
	- pragma solidity^0.4.16 (Faucet.sol#221): it allows old versions

vulnerability_findings.name: Dependence on predictable environment variable (SWC 120)
vulnerability_findings.message:
A control flow decision is made based on The block.number environment variable.
The block.number environment variable is used to determine a control flow decision. Note that the values of variables like coinbase, gaslimit, block number and timestamp are predictable and can be manipulated by a malicious miner. Also keep in mind that attackers know hashes of earlier blocks. Don't use any of those environment variables as sources of randomness and be aware that use of these variables introduces a certain level of trust into miners.
Classification: SWC-120

vulnerability_findings.name: External Call To User-Supplied Address (SWC 107)
vulnerability_findings.message:
A call to a user-supplied address is executed.
An external message call to an address specified by the caller is executed. Note that the callee account might contain arbitrary code and could re-enter any function within this contract. Reentering the contract in an intermediate state may lead to unexpected behaviour. Make sure that no state modifications are executed after this call and/or reentrancy guards are in place.
Classification: SWC-107

vulnerability_findings.name: Integer Arithmetic Bugs (SWC 101)
vulnerability_findings.message:
The arithmetic operator can overflow.
It is possible to cause an integer overflow or underflow in the arithmetic operation. 
Classification: SWC-101

vulnerability_findings.name: Integer Arithmetic Bugs (SWC 101)
vulnerability_findings.message:
The arithmetic operator can overflow.
It is possible to cause an integer overflow or underflow in the arithmetic operation. 
Classification: SWC-101

vulnerability_findings.name: State access after external call (SWC 107)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Read of persistent state following external call
The contract account state is accessed after an external call to a user defined address. To prevent reentrancy issues, consider accessing the state only before the call, especially if the callee is untrusted. Alternatively, a reentrancy lock can be used to prevent untrusted callees from re-entering the contract in an intermediate state.
Classification: SWC-107

vulnerability_findings.name: External Call To User-Supplied Address (SWC 107)
vulnerability_findings.message:
A call to a user-supplied address is executed.
An external message call to an address specified by the caller is executed. Note that the callee account might contain arbitrary code and could re-enter any function within this contract. Reentering the contract in an intermediate state may lead to unexpected behaviour. Make sure that no state modifications are executed after this call and/or reentrancy guards are in place.
Classification: SWC-107

vulnerability_findings.name: Multiple Calls in a Single Transaction (SWC 113)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Multiple calls are executed in the same transaction.
This call is executed following another call within the same transaction. It is possible that the call never gets executed if a prior call fails permanently. This might be caused intentionally by a malicious callee. If possible, refactor the code such that each transaction only executes one external call or make sure that all callees can be trusted (i.e. they’re part of your own codebase).
Classification: SWC-113

vulnerability_findings.name: State access after external call (SWC 107)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Write to persistent state following external call
The contract account state is accessed after an external call to a user defined address. To prevent reentrancy issues, consider accessing the state only before the call, especially if the callee is untrusted. Alternatively, a reentrancy lock can be used to prevent untrusted callees from re-entering the contract in an intermediate state.
Classification: SWC-107
